data.title: Unable to create windows installer when building; path and file name are too long.
data.body:

### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    [x] Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    [x] Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Running the script with the --create-windows-installer flag fails after throwing a PathTooLongException.

Output of script


### Steps to Reproduce

These steps assume all prerequisite software is installed (git, node.js, python, etc.) 

1. Open PowerShell
2. cd C:\
3. git clone https://github.com/atom/atom.git
4. cd atom
5. script\build --create-windows-installer

**Expected behavior:** A window installer gets created

**Actual behavior:** An exception is thrown and a windows installer is not created.

**Reproduces how often:**  100% of the time.  

### Versions

Windows 10 64-bit.  All versions are listed in script output above.

### Additional Information

This was a fresh build.  All of my pertinent software versions are listed.  Prior to trying to build atom from the source, I downloaded and installed atom.  I'm not sure if having an existing installation would cause issues with building a windows installer for atom, but that seems unlikely.  This looks like a bug in one of the build scripts.

data.title: Poor RTL support in the main editor.
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Poor support for RTL language.
RTL text is not highlitable.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. type some RTL Language like Arabic or Persian inside a quotation. Like this : "سلام این یک جمله فارسی است".
2. Try to select a word or a phrase from within the quote.
3. Or try to add a new word in the sentence. It's typed somewhere else... [magical] 

### Versions

Atom    : 1.19.7
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
OS : Windows 10

data.title: Text is pulsating at regular intervals in v1.21.0-beta0
data.body:
### Prerequisites

Done.

### Description

![atom-pulsating-text](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3703530/30348478-c6336416-980f-11e7-823a-900f7f5d4b12.gif)

I have a `transition: opacity 0.333s` on my cursor element, which causes this annoying pulsating effect. I assume that the transition causes Chromium to switch to a different way of rendering the texts, and voila. This was not an issue in either v1.19(.7?, latest stable version) or v1.20 (beta7 I think?), both used today.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Install `minimal-syntax-dark` (or add the transition on the cursor manually)
2. Create an empty JavaScript file
3. Enter some basic code, like `const test = "test"`

**Expected behavior:**

No pulsating text.

**Actual behavior:**

See .gif in description.

**Reproduces how often:**

Consistently.

### Versions

Atom v1.21.0-beta0 on macOS SIerra 10.12.6

data.title: No Numpad support in kaymap.cson?!?
data.body:
Why there is no Numpad support for keybinding? Oo

Almost every dirty editor can bind any key to a hotkey and some of them also can globally bind keys...

Tested:
```
'.platform-win32 .image-view':
  'ctrl-num-0': 'image-view:reset-zoom'
  'ctrl-num-insert': 'image-view:reset-zoom'

'.platform-win32 .markdown-preview, .platform-linux .markdown-preview':
  'ctrl-num-0': 'markdown-preview:reset-zoom'
  'ctrl-num-insert': 'markdown-preview:reset-zoom'
```
Does not wok at all!

data.title: Old app* folders and nupkg files left behind by Atom.
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * [ ] Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * [ ] Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * [X] Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * [X] Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * (N/A) Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Atom isn't cleaning up _AppData\Local\atom\app-*_ directories and _AppData\Local\atom\packages\atom-*.nupkg_ files.

### Steps to Reproduce

In short: Install an Atom update.

I only just noticed this, so I'll have to wait until the next Atom release before I can give more info about exactly what happens at update time.

**Expected behavior:** That files relating to old versions of Atom are deleted after update, except perhaps a backup of the most recent pre-update version of Atom (as described in #11586)

**Actual behavior:** None of the old versions of Atom are being deleted, and _nupkg_ files for old versions of Atom also remain. At time of writing, _\AppData\Local\atom_ contains more than 6 GB of files.

**Reproduces how often:** There's an _app-*_ directory and two _atom-*.nupkg_ files for all 1.19.x releases that I've installed (1.19.0 - 1.19.7; 8 in total), and there's also an _app-1.18.0_ directory (but no _nupkg_ files for 1.18.0).

### Versions

Windows 10 (Version 1607 build 14393.693)

Atom    : 1.19.7
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

apm  1.18.4
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 ia32
python 3.6.1
git 2.11.0.windows.3
visual studio 2013

### Additional Information

I've attached [AppData\Local\atom\SquirrelSetup.log](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/1295840/SquirrelSetup.log.txt), in case that helps.

data.title: Control palette focus issue
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Switching between the file search dialog and the control menu causes it to lose focus.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Click Cmd + P to trigger the file search dialog.
2. Without dismissing the dialog, click Cmd + Shift + P to switch to the control menu.

**Expected behavior:** The menu is focused (cursor in the search box)

**Actual behavior:** The menu lost focus (cursor in code file). Esc also doesn't work. I have to manually click the search box to focus it, and then esc to quit.

**Reproduces how often:** Everytime for me

### Versions

Atom 1.19.6, but it has been happening for a while. Mac 10.12.6.

data.title: Filebrowser should open in current workspace
data.body:
This is a feature request. Currently, when creating a new file, the file browser points to where it was last opened. When switching between projects, this is extremely unintuitive and takes time to move around in the browser. You should change it such that opening a new file points the file browser to the directory of the current project.

I'm on version 1.19.0 on macOS 10.12.6.

data.title: Issue with atom from command line in Windows 10
data.body:
Hi!

Basically, I've found an issue with Atom.cmd and PowerShell v5 (included in Windows 10). Problem is that PowerShell always complain about a pid not expected when executing an atom command from command line. apm is fine instead. A good guy at the atom.discuss forum tried to help me in resolving this issue, but the only workaround he found is to completely remove and offending line that invokes PowerShell by commenting the line out. Instead of repeating everything, I prefer to point out to the discussion, where the issue is explained in detail:
[https://discuss.atom.io/t/windows-10-help-manually-setting-command-line-variables/47308](url)

data.title: Make the atom.getReleaseChannel function public
data.body:
### Description of the Change

Make the `atom.getReleaseChannel` function public.

### Alternate Designs

The related functions such as `atom.getVersion` and `atom.isReleasedVersion` are already public, so I didn't believe that this should be any different.

### Why Should This Be In Core?

It already is.

### Benefits

People won't roll their own.

### Possible Drawbacks

Package authors may be more encouraged to make conditional code based on the release channel.

### Applicable Issues

N/A

data.title: Having two open atom instances with different ATOM_HOME causes the second instance to "share" partial state leading to unusual behavior in the secondary instance.
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

ATOM_HOME environment variable is not respected when another atom editor is already open. The editors appear to share partial state that leads to unusual behavior within plugins.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create 2 fresh workspaces and ensure there are no atom processes
```bash
$ cd /tmp
$ mkdir /tmp/ws{1,2}
$ ls ws*
> ws1:
> ws2:
$ ps --forest -o cmd -C atom
>   CMD
```

2. Start and close each atom process in sequence, being certain to not run concurrently. Just to get a good baseline.

```bash
$ export ATOM_HOME=/tmp/ws1
$ atom
$ ps --forest -o pid,cmd -C atom
> CMD
> /bin/bash /usr/bin/atom
>  \_ /usr/share/atom/atom --executed-from=/tmp --pid=12766
>      \_ /usr/share/atom/atom --type=zygote --no-sandbox
>      |   \_ /usr/share/atom/atom --type=renderer --enable-experimental-web-platform-features --no-sandbox --primordial-pipe-token=
>      |       \_ /usr/share/atom/atom /usr/share/atom/resources/app/src/task-bootstrap.js /tmp/ws1/compile-cache /usr/share/atom/re
>      \_ /usr/share/atom/atom --type=gpu-process --no-sandbox --supports-dual-gpus=false --gpu-driver-bug-workarounds=7,23,71 --gpu
$ # (close atom editor)
$ export ATOM_HOME=/tmp/ws2 
$ atom
$ ps --forest -o pid,cmd -C atom
> CMD
> /bin/bash /usr/bin/atom
>  \_ /usr/share/atom/atom --executed-from=/tmp --pid=13456
>      \_ /usr/share/atom/atom --type=zygote --no-sandbox
>      |   \_ /usr/share/atom/atom --type=renderer --enable-experimental-web-platform-features --no-sandbox --primordial-pipe-token=
>      |       \_ /usr/share/atom/atom /usr/share/atom/resources/app/src/task-bootstrap.js /tmp/ws2/compile-cache /usr/share/atom/re
>     \_ /usr/share/atom/atom --type=gpu-process --no-sandbox --supports-dual-gpus=false --gpu-driver-bug-workarounds=7,23,71 --gpu
$ # (close second atom editor)
$ ls ws*
> ws1:
> compile-cache  config.cson  github.cson  nohup.out  storage
>
> ws2:
> compile-cache  config.cson  github.cson  nohup.out  storage
```

3. Open **ws1** all by itself and install "linter", then close it I can run  **ws2** and get no prompts to install Linter dependencies nor do I see "linter" in my "installed" packages.

4. Open **ws1** and minimize it.
5. Open **ws2** and begin getting a "prompt" to install linter dependencies, though it does not show up in installed packages. 

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

Two completely independent editors with no plugins appearing in the second workspace. I am not sure if that is the intent of ATOM_HOME- but it has worked well for me since I first started using item (around it's release). I don't often (if ever) have two different workspaces open at the same time so I am not sure if this behavior was added in a recent version or always existed. At the very least I don't want it to break my second workspace, but I'm not sure if that is possible without all plugins being separate.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

The editors do not operate under independent HOME directories. What exactly merges between the two systems is not entirely clear to me from testing. Here for example we saw the "Linter" base package appears in **workspace#1** installed packages and the dependency prompt successfully installs the ui dependency. In **workspace#2** however it does not show under "installed" packages, though a prompt comes up to install Linter dependencies. Once dependencies are installed it still does not show under "installed" packages which is rather confusing.

The behavior gets much more unpredictable when you have two workspaces that are very different, for example I have a "work" workspace that uses different plugin versions (or missing some plugins all together) than my "home" workspace. If I open the second workspace without closing my "home" workspace .. the erorrs and prompts begin. Complains about config keys, it tries to install "missing" plugin dependencies and seems to have "broken" the "secondary" workspace entirely as it seems the config was mutated (upgraded perhaps by out of date plugins?) simply by opening it. An example of the biggest nuisance here would be `go-plus` which is not installed on my "work" workspace beginning to try install a bunch of binaries to my $GOPATH of my "work" workspace despite the plugin not being installed when ran independently.

Most important note: **Restoring both workspaces to initial state and opening each one in sequence with the proper *ATOM_HOME* and related env vars (at most 1 open at a time) each editor works perfectly and I can switch back and forth from the same terminal with no issues.**

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%

### Versions

```bash
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.19.1
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
$ apm --version
apm  1.18.4
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4
$ uname -a
Linux cws 4.11.0-13-generic #19~16.04.1-Ubuntu SMP Wed Aug 2 20:06:21 UTC 2017 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```

### Additional Information

I attempted to find a related ATOM_HOME bug but nothing that was about this specific issue.

data.title: "Find in file" not always linear results with "find next"
data.body: Windows 10: This issue is not only in atom. I have see this in pspad too. (editor I use before atom) So maybe this is a bug in windows? This not happen every time, its a little random. I press STRG+F to search a string and replace this with a other text from clipboard. Now I press F3 to find next result and replace with clipboard (SHIFT+INSERT) again and from time to time its jump to a later result. Simple example: find results in line 3, 5, 7, 21, 9, 11. You see line 21 between line 7 and 9? That should not happen with press F3. But again, I see this issue in "pspad" too with windows 8.1 and windows 10.

data.title: Spelling
data.body:
### Description of the Change

Spelling fixes

### Alternate Designs

<!-- Explain what other alternates were considered and why the proposed version was selected -->
None of the misspellings appeared particularly intentional.

### Why Should This Be In Core?

<!-- Explain why this functionality should be in atom/atom as opposed to a package -->
Misspellings hurt project health.

### Benefits

<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->
It's easier to use healthier projects, and there are fewer errors when people try to write code with the expected spelling (which doesn't match the used misspelling).

### Possible Drawbacks

It's possible that a misspelling is intentional, or that it's an APIand thus is hard to change (JavaScript and stylesheet are the only likely candidates in this series).

data.title: [Workaround] Fix for newly added project folder having git related view issues
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I've noted a high number of git related issues marked as bug with the following files/folders.
- `.gitignore`
- `.git` folder

This workaround is for newly created project folders not adding in git visuals in the treeview interface.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a directory
2. Add the newly created directory as a new project folder
 - `File > Add Project Folder`
3. Navigate to the directory via CLI and execute `git init`
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8001375/30244712-743c0196-9589-11e7-9538-867b6e0571ef.png)
 - First, note that the directory has not been recognized as a git repo in the tree view.
 - Second, the `.git` directory has not been recognized as a hidden folder
 - Third, **if you proceed as if nothing is wrong, `.gitignore` will not "darken/hide" files properly**.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8001375/30244736-c1814a10-9589-11e7-8211-90caa430d367.png)
4. To fix this, remove the **project folder** (not the actual directory) in the tree view and add it back.
 - 😄 All fixed
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8001375/30244750-f6a97866-9589-11e7-8afa-dc79150baf90.png)

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
Tree view recognizes the project folder being initialized to a git repo and updates

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
Tree view does not recognize the project folder being initialized as a git repo and does not implement additional git functionality as a result.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100% of the time

### Versions

Windows 10 Pro 10.0.15063 Build 15063

```
Atom    : 1.19.7
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

### Notes

While this functionality is a bit of a feature and the implementation required to detect a change as to whether or not the folder has been initialized git repo after addition may prove impractical, I believe this process may prove invaluable to further debug actual issues.
